thread.title: Deputy Chief Molloy remembered for heroism on 9/11 at funeral
thread.title_full: Deputy Chief Molloy remembered for heroism on 9/11 at funeral

author: ANTHONY IZAGUIRRE, RICH SCHAPIRO
title: Deputy Chief Molloy remembered for heroism on 9/11 at funeral

locations.name: st. patrick's church in bay shore

text:
Deputy Chief James Molloy, who died of 9/11-linked brain cancer, remembered as hard-working NYPD cop at funeral Deputy Chief Molloy remembered for heroism on 9/11 at funeral A slow-rolling vintage green emergency service vehicle ferried Deputy Chief James Molloy’s casket to the church. (David Wexler/For New York Daily News) NEW YORK DAILY NEWS  33 PM 
A Long Island church turned into a sea of blue Friday as more than 500 NYPD officers bade farewell to a beloved chief who died of a 9/11-related brain cancer . 
A standing-room only crowd packed into The Parish of St. Patrick in Bay Shore where Deputy Chief James Molloy, 55, was eulogized as a cop’s cop and “bad ass” father. 
“He endured the merciless pain of cancer with grace,” added Molloy’s 25-year-old daughter Alexa. 
Alexa Molloy described her father as a master handyman who built almost everything in the house and religiously changed the oil in the family cars whenever they hit 3,000 miles. 
NYPD Deputy Chief James Molloy dies of 9/11-related brain cancer 
“Everything he did, he did thoroughly,” she said. NYPD Commissioner O'Neill (c.) stands with other members of the Finest outside St. Patrick's Church in Bay Shore Friday for Molloy’s funeral. (David Wexler/For New York Daily News) 
Police Commissioner James O’Neill noted that Molloy served more than a dozen commands in a decorated career that spanned 35 years. 
“September 11th was a painful day in New York City history and more than 15 years later it still hurts," he said. “Our heroes from that day are still dying.” 
The married father of two died Jan. 30 after a 2½-year battle with cancer. 
Molloy was driving to work on the morning of Sept. 11, 2001,when the World Trade Center came under attack. The finest salute the late Molloy as the funeral proceeds down the street in Bay Shore. (David Wexler/For New York Daily News) 
As the towers burned, Molloy was stuck in traffic inside the Brooklyn Battery Tunnel, O’Neill said. 
Massive waves of debris filled the underpass after the towers crumbled to the ground. 
Coated in dust, Molloy rushed to Ground Zero to help lead the recovery effort. 
“With every breath, he was giving his life for the people of this great city,” O’Neill said. Molloy’s family follows pallbearers carrying the deceased’s casket Friday into the church. (David Wexler/For New York Daily News) 
“But that was his calling, because he was a New York City cop. And he was a great one.” 
NYPD Lt. Eugene Whyte recalled bonding with Molloy after 9/11 when they were tasked with the grim job of identifying slain police officers. 
Molloy was quick to comfort any cops who walked into the morgue and appeared overwhelmed by the sight of the fallen officers, Whyte said. 
“He was down to earth and took good care of his guys,” Whyte said. 
A slow-rolling vintage green emergency service vehicle ferried Molloy’s casket to the church. 
The hundreds of cops gathered outside gave Molloy a final salute as six officers hoisted his flag-draped coffin onto their shoulders and marched into the house of worship. Tags:
